title: Is the USC School of Cinematic Arts BFA in screenwriting worth it? - Quora

response.answer_text: If you are simply trying to learn the basics of screenwriting, then no. Although, if you are considering this prestigious school, then I have a few criteria that you should look for: The screenwriting instructor should not give you the worn out piece of advice: “Write what you know”, because when you write what you know, there is a high probability that you may be writing what the audience has seen like a zillion times already. The instructor should encourage you to write what the audience knows on whatever topic your script is about. It's kind of like writing an academic essay where you find out what your target audience (the reader) knows about the topic and what new information you can bring to the table. Same with your script. What is something new that you know about your film that your audience doesn't know about the film. Think long and hard about that.The screenwriting instructor teaching the class should encourage you to come up with quality ideas rather than just take an idea of yours and help you write the screenplay. Industry readers and critics alike are purposely looking for anything and everything wrong with your screenplay.The screenwriting instructor should set up workshops that will allow you effectively formulate descriptions that are visually concise, and that will leap off the page so that your storytelling capabilities using words keeps the reader interested.When the first class commences, the instructor better not ask the question: “Why do we watch movies”. Why do we watch movies? This is a screenwriting class. The more appropriate question/discussion within the class should be: “Why do we tell stories”. You might want to refer to the heavily popular book: Sapiens.As an alternative and as a cheaper option, I would recommend you consider visiting the website of ScreenwritingU | Screenwriting Classes, Services & Products (ScreenwritingU) and learning more about the screenwriting course they offer, because the founder is an expert and the course is based on what the founder refers to as an expert model.

Screenwriters craft blueprints for the material manifestation of imagination. Our work is done at the friction point between the formless and the physical.  USC’s rep as a preeminent film school is well earned. One of the best, no doubt. The teachers, the equipment, the legacy — somewhere in the world’s top 5. To this day, I rely on insights from remarkable teachers like Howard Rodman, David Howard, Jack Epps, on and on. They’re the real thing. If your question is, “Do I need to go to film school, USC or otherwise, to become the best screenwriter I can be?” The answer is probably, No. If your question is, “Will going to a top film school like USC open doors in the film industry?” Unfortunately, the answer is maybe. Some might even claim there’s a bias against USC film students using their degree as a calling card. In some instances, they might be right. Why this bias? It’s common for fresh graduates from top film schools to come off as “better than” by the fact of the program’s exclusivity. Keep in mind, many successful filmmakers didn’t get in or couldn’t afford a school like SC. If you trigger egos in the industry, you’ll get push back every time. More unfairly, the — “USC stands for University of Spoiled Children” joke — is pretty much ingrained despite USC’s objective excellence as an educational institution. The recent scandals of the wealthy buying their way into USC didn’t help matters. Regardless, USC’s exclusive status will get eyeballs on your script. The question is — is the price worth the read? Maybe. To say about film degrees, “No one in the industry gives a sh**” might be a bit harsh. Yet, I’ve heard that more than a few times. We all learn right away the gap between film school and real world filmmaking is about the difference between playing football at a top prep school and the NFL. Firstly — all anyone will care about is if your script is good. Secondly, they evaluate — can we work with this person? Benefit of film school If there’s truth in what I’ve said, then why would anyone want to goto film school? What are the benefits? The main value of going to film school is to meet other filmmakers. Paraphrasing USC alum John August — you goto film school to meet your collaborators, your support group, your rivals, your life-long friends, your life-long enemies — you go to find your community. You go to form your tribe. Your ability to garner and foster working relationships will be the determining factor of success as a screenwriter. An introvert such as myself hated to hear that way back when. I stubbornly clutched onto the delusion that my scripts will be so brilliant, my talent so undeniable, that I won’t need to network, market myself, or approach my career as an entrepreneur building a business where the sole product was — me. Despite being an expert in screenplay structure, you haven’t heard of me as a screenwriter, right? There you go. Talent is not enough. In the pros — everyone is talented. Everyone can write. “It’s not who you are, but who you know that matters,” is a half truth at best. Who you know may open a door or two, a time or two — but it’s who you are that determines if you stay in the room. In the old days, you goto film school for access to the technology — for a chance to make a film. This has not been the case for decades. How many films has Soderbergh made on his iPhone by now? Didn’t Sean Baker make his Sundance darling Tangerine on a iPhone 5? Not 11, not 10 — iPhone 5. So if going to film school to learn screenwriting may not give you the best ROI (return on investment), what BA degree would be most helpful in a screenwriter’s career? In this screenwriter’s opinion — Marketing Internet marketing to be more precise. Learn to market yourself. Learn how to garner and foster relationships. Learn how to pitch an idea. Learn how to sell an idea. Learn how to sell yourself. Learn about IP (intellectual properties). Learn about contracts. Learn about contract negotiations. Learn how to monetize your emotional labor. Learn how to monetize your words, your art. A degree in a marketing related discipline could be a source of income across lifespan. For the first phase of your career, you’ll likely be working for the privilege of pursuing your art. If you can support yourself through means that generate passive income, you’ll earn more free time to devote to a career path that will be predicated largely on back pay rationalizations. John August said this about finding agents and managers — “Rather than asking ‘how can I find an agent or manager’ ask ‘how can an agent or manager find me’?” Great advice. How? Marketing. How did Diablo Cody get discovered? Look that up. Marketing. Do you have the skills to grow a significant internet presence? If you do, you’ll stand above the fray and earn notice. Consider the odds What is the employment rate for screenwriters? The WGA website has all those metrics. Please look those up. Know what you’re getting into. Meryl Streep said of acting (paraphrasing) — If there’s anything else on Earth you can do, do that. For her, she had no other option. Acting was the only way she could fulfill her soul. Same goes for screenwriting. Writer or filmmaker? If you love writing for the words — meaning you love novels, poetry — you’re a word smith, you love expressing through the literary art — consider this truth about screenwriting — The words of the screenwriter are not meant to be read by the audience. If you can paint emotive visuals like Cormac McCarthy through poetic descriptions, or reveal trans-generational trauma through a five page description of a grandfather clock like Stephen King — consider that those elements will be the first trash bin edits you make in your screenplay. Not the right medium. If you relish the perfection of a well crafted, grammatically true sentence - consider that screenplays are written in present tense, often grammar-violating fragments, at a 9th grade complexity level for optimal functionality. It’s not about the words. It’s about dramatizing actions and emotions. “It’s not motion pictures, it’s E-motion pictures,” said a USC prof. We are creating blueprints to be interpreted and manifested by the director and crew. We are part of the filmmaking team. Features or Television? Feature film is a director’s medium. Writers are often expendable. For every film that makes it to the theaters, there’s likely many writers who were not credited. Television is more a writer’s medium. The writers rule TV. So if screenwriting is your only option, strongly consider going into television. Employment opportunities far out number features. The caveat — TV writers work in teams. You have to play well with others. How apt are you in working in groups? Office politics? How apt are you in selling your ideas? How good are you at — marketing yourself. All comes back to marketing. I’ll offer suggestions for learning the craft independent of film school. Scriptnotes podcast and I strongly suggest listening to the Scriptnotes podcast by two insanely successful screenwriters — John August and Craig Mazin.  John has a website that is a wealth of generously gifted information. You can search your question on film school for screenwriters on that site. Both John and Craig have strong opinions on that very topic. If anyone would know — those two would. If fact, I highly suggest you listen to every episode of Scriptnotes before making your decision. Get it from top industry, award winning, altruistic professionals. Get it straight from the source. John and Craig pocket not a dime from their podcast. They made it — and they want to give back — period. Rare. Role Models No need to reinvent the wheel. Choose role models in filmmakers with qualities you want to emulate. Choose role models more similar to yourself than not. Compartmentalize your role models for the specific quality you wish to develop. I’ll go into detail of role model specificity as an example — Mindset role model: Justin Lin (Notice the specificity of the qualities I’m role modeling) I refer to Justin Lin as the Kobe Bryant (RIP) of filmmaking. That guy can make a billion dollar juggernaut from concept to completion in two years. That is insanity. He made Star Trek Beyond organically, forming the script as he shot — as if he were making an indie. Fearless. (Notice how I’m accentuating the specific targets of improvement) Justin has a warrior mindset, an engine that won’t quit. No one out works him. He elevates those around him — because the better they are, the better the film. Show the same passion and work ethic, he’ll give you a chance — because work ethic and passion are a film’s life blood. Get in the way of the filmmaking, he’ll dunk on your head. It’s all about the filmmaking. Dedication, fierce desire to grow, no excuses — just get it done. I chose Justin as a role model for our commonalities. He’s Taiwanese-American, he’s close in age, from southern cal. Relatability in choosing role models is the key. I could have chosen Steven Spielberg (my filmmaking idol), but relatability would be an issue. It’s too easy for me to say, “Yeah, but he’s Steven Spielberg — the legend. I’m nothing like him.” By choosing a role model I share characteristics with, the realm of possibility focuses. In Justin, all my excuses are invalidated by the fact of his existence. When I feel like I’m too old, I say “Justin’s my age.” When I’m too tired I say, “Justin works till wee hours and is running miles before next day’s work.” More examples, in less detail — Emotional Intelligence role model: John August John’s the guy they bring in to work with titans of the industry. He’s not intimidating, but not the least bit intimidated. John is similar in age, not straight, and is not the ruthless assassin many feel they need to be in order to succeed. John is an example that kindness, decency, and integrity are strengths rather than deficiencies in the industry. Artistic role model: Ang Lee Again, he is Asian-American, from the same culture, got his break later in life, faced the same unique challenges that Asian filmmakers struggle with. Relatability. Trade knowledge role model: Ernesto Foronda Producer, writer, filmmaker, festival programmer. That guy sees and reads everything. Prolific in consuming and retention of content. My age-ish, Asian-American, etc. Relatable. Screenwriting role model: Chris Nolan Similar sensibility and cognitive approach to screenplay construction. I watch one of his films and I can almost see the ink strokes of his blueprint. I can go on and on. One relatable role model for each characteristic I’m trying to develop. I have close to 30. Permission to write bad screenplays Writers write. If you’re not writing screenplays, you’re not a screenwriter. At the end of the day, you learn screenwriting by screenwriting. Give yourself permission to write bad screenplays. Write ten bad screenplays. See what happens. You learn from your mistakes, from wasting hundreds of hours going down blind alleys and story beats that belong on the editing room floor. Your success will be a function of your experience. How do you get experience? You make every mistake imaginable and learn from them. Great work if you can find it The odds are against you. The competition is fierce. If you can carve a career path in screenwriting, there’s potential for a type of artistic fulfillment that is altogether unique. Screenwriters craft blueprints for the material manifestation of imagination. Our work is done at the friction point between the formless and the physical. It’s one of the toughest jobs on the filmmaking team. You’re starting from a blank page. The entire team from producer to intern is relying on your execution. It’s terrifying and at the same time thrilling. “Screenwriters are not special people, but I believe the craft of screenwriting is.” (Craig Mazin). Doing it at a high level is as difficult as composing an orchestral piece, l’ve heard musician-writers claim. Screenwriting is an art form unlike any other. If there’s anything else on Earth I can do, I would. Do your art Lastly, read Seth Godin’s, The Icarus Deception.  We are past the Information Age, moving into the Age of Connection. Connection is created by the conduit of art. Art is created by emotional labor. It’s a new world. And the world is ready for — Your art. Thanks for the A2A. It’s an important question for a big decision. Thanks for the opportuntiy to share. Grateful.

These type of value judgment questions are almost always exactly backwards. The question is not whether USC is worth it, but whether your abilities are worth USC. There’s a lot more to success than knowledge, and it’s not like SC teaches some dark arts version of Film. You can get a functioning education with essentially the required utility from lots of places. USC is just additional leverage. The only thing that matters is whether or not you are the kind of person who will exploit that leverage. If so then SC is probably worth every penny. if not, go to community college and major in some other career field.

As one who’s been there and left it, let me say this. If you want to know how to write a screenplay, read Syd Fields’ book, “Screenplay.” If you want to know about story structure, read Lajos Egri’s “The Art of Dramatic Writing.” That’s all you need to learn, and learn them well. The rest is sitting your butt in a chair, churning them out, then hustling them through the Hollywood streets every moment you aren’t writing. In the end, you either have talent or you don’t. 90% of the WGA has never sold a second screenplay. So, in my opinion, spending $120,000 to learn these simple realities isn’t worth it.
